DataElement.preferredName: Breast Primary Invasive Adenocarcinoma Histologically Confirmed Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body, of established or verified by the use of histology or histological techniques of primary invasive breast adenocarcinoma (a malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization).

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Breast Primary Invasive Adenocarcinoma Histologically Confirmed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to having been established or verified by the use of histology or histological techniques primary invasive breast adenocarcinoma (a malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.:Occurring first in time or sequence; original. (American Heritage Dictionary):marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue.:carcinoma derived from glandular tissue or in which tumor cells form recognizable glandular structures.

Concepts.definition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.
Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.
Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.

A common cancer characterized by the presence of malignant glandular cells.  Morphologically, adenocarcinomas are classified according to the growth pattern (e.g., papillary, alveolar) or according to the secreting product (e.g., mucinous, serous).  Representative examples of adenocarcinoma are ductal and lobular breast carcinoma, lung adenocarcinoma, renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma (hepatoma), colon adenocarcinoma, and prostate adenocarcinoma.

Property.preferredDefinition: Involving the use of histology or histological techniques.:Confirmed; having been established or verified.

Concepts.definition: Involving the use of histology or histological techniques.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body of confirmed adenocarcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Invasive cancer confined to the original anatomic site of growth without lymph node involvement.

Concepts.definition: Invasive cancer confined to the original anatomic site of growth without lymph node involvement.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Invasive cancer more extensive than stage I, usually involving local lymph nodes without spread to distant anatomic sites.

Concepts.definition: Invasive cancer more extensive than stage I, usually involving local lymph nodes without spread to distant anatomic sites.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Locally advanced cancer that has spread to nearby organs but not to distant anatomic sites.

Concepts.definition: Locally advanced cancer that has spread to nearby organs but not to distant anatomic sites.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Stage II High Risk Node Negative Finding

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Stage II High Risk Node Negative Finding
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Invasive cancer more extensive than stage I, usually involving local lymph nodes without spread to distant anatomic sites.: The potential future harm that may arise from some present action or attribute or condition is almost certain.: Any bulge or swelling of an anatomical structure or part.: A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

Concepts.definition: Invasive cancer more extensive than stage I, usually involving local lymph nodes without spread to distant anatomic sites.
The potential future harm that may arise from some present action or attribute or condition is almost certain.
Any bulge or swelling of an anatomical structure or part.
A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.
